page.title: 05Local History Leighton Woods
page.content: John Naylor, owner of Leighton Hall, planted the woodlands and landscaped the estate in the 1850"s. Some exotic trees were planted in small groups in the forests. Today 80% of the trees are coniferous, mainly Douglas fir and larch. One of the Grand Fir Trees is the largest in Great Britain, 170ft. high. {The Redwood Grove} The "Charles Ackers" Redwood Grove is now the property of the Royal Forestry Society. The 33 trees were brought over from California as seedlings in pots in 1858. The name Sequoia sempervirens honours a famous Cherokee Chief, and sempervirens means "always living". It is difficult to kill off the Redwoods. The bark will not burn easily - it is soft, spongy and thick.Fallen trees throw vertical shoots from the trunk.
